text: The funding more than doubles the emergency relief available to students and institutions already authorized under the previous two COVID-19 relief bills.

Stabenow: I look forward to hearing from all our witnesses today.
Stabenow: Secondly, as we think about reaping additional climate benefits from managed timberland, we also need to redouble our efforts to protect the few remaining stands of old-growth forests.

Stabenow: First, we need to ensure that climate smart forestry policies and practices complement and strengthen our traditional forest products markets. In fact, I think there‚Äôs great promise in storing carbon in long-lived wood products like mass timber.

Stabenow: Small-acreage and minority landowners have too often been left out of the kind of opportunities we‚Äôre talking about today. Their stories are unique, and their needs may be very different than those of larger or more-resourced operations.

Stabenow: Climate-smart forestry policies offer both tools to reduce carbon pollution and an important opportunity to develop new revenue streams for family foresters. This helps provide financial stability in uncertain times.
Stabenow: America‚Äôs forests currently pull as much carbon dioxide out of the air every year as eliminating 54 million cars from the road according to the National Academy of Science.

I call on Congress to pass my Big Cat bill. I call on the @USDA to do a much, much better job enforcing the animal welfare laws we currently have on the books. 

But it‚Äôs not just about government.

I call on all of us to do better by the animals we share this planet with.

But this is about each one of us understanding and acting as though every living thing deserves respect and nothing, no matter what species, deserves to suffer the way far too many animals in the United States are suffering right now.

I'm the author of the #BigCatPublicSafetyAct and the Federal #BirdSafeBuildings Act. I'm a member of the Congressional Animal Protection Caucus and I'll do my part to make sure that our government is looking out for those who can't look out for themselves.
...rather than being shipped overseas to an uncertain fate. That story had a happy ending but I was still struck by the callousness and cruelty that lead to the situation in the first place.

It's not just big cats. In August, twenty French bulldog puppies were abandoned in a warehouse at O'Hare airport and left in cages for days before being discovered by a policeman and rescued. One died. I was glad to help navigate the bureaucracy to ensure those dogs could stay...

As a pet owner, an animal lover, and a human being, I am disgusted by the thought of any animal being subjected to torture, abuse, and utter indifference from the day of its birth. We must be better than this.

RT @GovDunleavy The return of cruise ships to Alaska is a tremendous victory for our small businesses, families & state! Thanks to the tireless work of our state team, local leaders, businesses & our Congressional Delegation, the industry can resume sailings...
Our bill is now on its way to the President‚Äôs desk to be signed into law, and cruise passengers will soon be able to safely experience everything our state has to offer!

Canada closed their ports, effectively ending our cruise season. Under the Alaska Tourism Restoration Act, the Canadian port stop required under the Passenger Vessel Services Act is no longer necessary.
It was all hands on deck, and our gamble paid off. I want to thank @lisamurkowski, @SenDanSullivan, our staffs, and the countless stakeholders who help make this happen.

We were counted out; our mom and pop businesses that depend on tourism were told to simply get through to 2022; however, our small but mighty Delegation got it done. I worked with everyone on both sides of the aisle: @SpeakerPelosi, @LeaderHoyer, @GOPLeader, and @POTUS.
